Isn't the whole point of REST that URIs should be
opaque when describing a web service?

Regarding what I am trying to do, I want to expose
a mailfolder via HTTP.  Three things may happen
to this mailfolder:

* The server may choose to move attachments to
   external URLs
* The server may change those external URLs
* New messages may be added to the folder
Note: Messages will not be deleted from the folder.

I want clients:
1. to be able to rertrieve the entire folder
2. to be able to retreive only messages that have
   been added to the folder without retrieving
   already received messages whose representations
   have changed

I would like to have a large number of anonymous
clients so I don't want to force the server to
maintain a state for each client (as required by
'mark and move' servers).

My proposed solution is to return
multipart/byteranges as a response to queries with
etags.  I suppose I could also return any diff
format, but I'm not aware of one that is
particularly better suited to this problem than
multipart/byteranges.

Is the consensus that this is HTTP-OK, and if so
what is the correct status code to return?

-Alex-

On Tue, 7 Jan 2003, S. Mike Dierken wrote:

>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
>
> > Isn't adding a query term "received-since" unRESTful?
> I don't think so. But I am not bothered by constructing URIs on the client.
>
> Also, I meant 'modified-since' - I mis-edited the paragraph before sending
> it. It is intended to represent a resource that is a list of items that have
> been modified since a certain time.
>
> If I understand what you are trying to do, you have a single resource with a
> list of messages. The content of the response may change somewhere in the
> middle - e.g. the href attribute of the fifth item.
> You would like to talk to this same resource, yet receive only those
> portions (or items) that have changed since some previous response,
> indicated by either eTag or last-modified or something.
> The change to the resource isn't that a new message has arrived - you can
> use the 'mark and move' approach to clean out the inbox for that - but that
> the storage location of attachments has changed.
>
> If you have multiple collections of messages, then each collection of
> messages probably needs to support this 'list only changed items since xyz'
> capability.
>
> I can't help but think that using byte-range is fragile - deltas on dynamic
> content seems problematic. I'd recommend a content format that is more
> suited to having the client merge updates to a list of items.
>
>
